instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3215: What is CD3215? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..
definitions.PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC: What is PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC? PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO is an LDO coming out of the CD3215 USB-C muxing chip. When this is missing, either a capacitor on the line has shorted, PP3V3_G3H is missing, or the CD3215 is bad..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
Charger (genuine 87W) was working only on one side of USB C port and there was 5V and sometimes 20V (was charging fine but when connected any USB device was not visible in macOS) but when use other side of charging cable there was nothing on ampmeter.

Replaced <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and both side are working but both stuck at 5V and 0A.

<SIGNAL>PP3V3RV0_AON</SIGNAL> in diode mode 0.550V.
<CHIP>CD3250</CHIP> LDOs diode mode readings are OK.

Where to start?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
Do you get correct LDO voltages on <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip?
You may have bad solders, or bad <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_UPC_XA_LDO_BMC</SIGNAL> got 0.15V (0.460V in diode mode).
Rest LDOs got correct voltages.

Changed <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> and still the same issue - tested with board only (no battery).

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
You had working machine before replacing <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> chip.
If new chip is really good, then bad solders, or knocked off components.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V 0A
threads.message:
<CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> batch was faulty :/
Used another <CHIP>CD3215</CHIP> all works fine now on both sides :)

Thank you very much :)
